isis.stitle: RECONDITIONING BRAKE DRUMS AND SHOES - BRAKE DRUMS - INSPECTION

svcprocinfo.para: As part of the brake inspection it is important to learn to recognize the various clues offered by a brake drum when it is first removed from the vehicle.

It is important to take the time to closely read the wear patterns and markings of a worn drum. A great deal can be learned about the vehicles braking performance and even help prevent premature wear or failure of a new brake job.
It is important to watch for the following conditions. They indicate if the drum needs servicing or replacing.

svcsubproc.title: Cracked Drums ( Figure 1)
svcsubproc.para: This is caused by excessive heating and cooling. The system should be checked for balance, paying particular attention to using brake material with the proper friction rating as recommended by International. Replace cracked drums immediately.

svcsubproc.title: Heat-Checking ( Figure 2)
svcsubproc.para: This condition is indicated when the brake drum braking surface shows fine, hairline cracks. Heat-checking is a normal condition of the brake drum caused by constant heating and cooling of the braking surface.

svcsubproc.title: Out-Of-Round Drums ( Figure 3)
svcsubproc.para: This condition is signified by more wear on one side of the brake lining and variations in drum diameter at different points on the braking surface.

The drum should be machined to within allowable limitations, to restore concentricity or be replaced with a new drum. Drums should not be machined to exceed maximum rebore limit of .080" and not be worn to exceed .120".

svcsubproc.title: Oversized Drums ( Figure 4)
svcsubproc.para: This condition is indicated by uneven lining wear, or braking surface diameter measurements in excess of allowable limitations. Corrective action would include the replacement of the brake drum and brake lining.

svcsubproc.title: Grease Stained Drums ( Figure 5)
svcsubproc.para: Upon inspection, there will be discolored spots on the drum surface, with oil or grease splattered on the brake assembly.
The condition may be caused by a faulty seal or improper greasing of the brake cams.
To correct the condition it is necessary to repair the oil or grease leak, clean the entire assembly and replace the lining if it is soaked with oil or grease.

svcsubproc.title: Heat Spotted Drums ( Figure 6)
svcsubproc.para: This problem may be indicated by hard, slightly raised, dark colored spots on the braking surface with uneven wear. This problem may also be indicated by a pulsating ride upon application of the brakes or excessive noise when braking.

Drums should be turned to remove the hard, raised areas. If boring or grinding will not remove the spots, the drum should be replaced. Brake linings should also be checked for uneven wear factors and replaced to restore maximum braking efficiency.

svcsubproc.title: Scored Drums ( Figure 7)
svcsubproc.para: The condition is indicated by a grooved appearance on the braking surface of the drum and excessive lining wear.

The scoring can be removed by machining within established limitations. It is also advisable to closely inspect the entire brake system to determine if excessive amounts of braking material have entered the braking system.

svcsubproc.title: Blue Drums ( Figure 8)
svcsubproc.para: This condition is signified by a bluish color and disfiguration of the brake parts and is caused by excessive heat. The system should be checked for broken or weak return springs and possible faulty operation of the brake cams.

svcsubproc.title: Polished Drums ( Figure 9)
svcsubproc.para: A polished drum can be recognized from a mirror-like finish on the braking surface.
This condition is easily corrected by removing the gloss with eighty grit emery cloth. If the condition reappears, linings should be checked for proper friction rating.

svcsubproc.title: Excessive Wear ( Figure 10)
svcsubproc.para: If excessive wear occurs along the edges of the lining contact area or in areas coinciding with the lining rivet holes, the system should be checked for abrasive material collection.
Brake drums should be checked for scoring and replaced if severely damaged.

svcsubproc.title: Barrel-Shaped Drums ( Figure 11)
svcsubproc.para: A barrel-shaped drum results from overheating. If this condition is not corrected, the braking surface is reduced and uneven lining wear results.

svcsubproc.title: Bellmouthed Drum ( Figure 12)
svcsubproc.para: Extreme pressure over a period of time will create a bellmouthed drum. Brake lining on a bellmouthed brake drum will make contact only on the inner surface of the drum. In addition to cutting the braking surface to a minimum, it will also cause uneven and rapid lining wear.

svcsubproc.title: Runout ( Figure 13)
svcsubproc.para: Any time a new brake drum is to be installed on a vehicle, the runout should be checked as follows. Place the new drum with hub and wheel assembled in brake drum lathe making certain drum is centered. Mount Dial Indicator on lathe and check runout about 0.5 inch (12.7mm) in from edge of drum (on braking surface) as shown in Figure 13. Runout must not exceed 0.010 inch (0.25 mm).
